ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I wouldn't recommend the course in its current form. The instructor didn't seem to be as invested in the course as I would like him to be. The models were too theoretical and were suitable for a PhD student and not for an applied degree.

The course was interesting but the final paper did not seem to coincide well with the lectures. I would have liked more direction with the paper and more support. However, I would still recommend the class to a peer.
It is a really good course if you want to know about what development projects are going on around the globe, or if you want to pursue a Phd in Development.
A broad overview of some applied papers in the subject of development.
An interesting, if somewhat mechanical, overview of development economic theories and some applied assessments thereof.
Would not recommend this course to anyone who is going into policy work in the future. Too technical and academic - suitable for PhD students only or those intending to pursue intensive research.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Give me hands on experience of different development models
Learnt more about specific uses of stata during section.

I learned important skills in applied research, however, this course only gave me a light nudge in the right direction, almost everything I learned through the process of this course was due to my own efforts and work rather than the teaching.
The empirical parts of the class gave useful background knowledge. TA's Stata sections were helpful (though perhaps should have been run through econometrics classes).
This course is not helpful for my profession/foreseeable future at all. I would rather not have taken this course but it is a core requirement.
